title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: Those old houses stood upon Scottish soil; thoserolling wooded hills, stretching away Northward, werestudded with Scottish shielings; and the women who satknitting at the doors, and the children running in and out,spoke with the soft " b-r-r-r of the border" to which thetongue of the Southron is so inevitably a stranger : do I doany discredit to American manhood in saying that as weswept over the long, narrow stone bridge spanni'ief theTweed with the river glancing silver below, and reachedthe thither embankment which so surely marked the oldbouudary between the two countries,—I took off my hatwith such a reverence as I might have felt on entering anold cathedral ; and risked the washing off of the paint ofdandyhood from my face, by letting two or three self-willedtears make Tweeds of their own down the furrows, andspoke aloud, more to myself than to my single companion,what the heart echoed most fervently: "Puir auld Scotland ! bonnie, brave, glorious auld Scotland ! God bless youand yours, forever ! "But the Berwick that we saw was principally a railroadstation with its surroundings of spare cars and turn-out rails ;the stout fellows in blue bonnets, whom I saw around therailway station, were thinking far more of the stern realityof labor and the pleasant reality of that pay following labor,than of anything in the old feudal days ; and the crews ofthe little boats which I saw dropping away below the bridge,down the mouth of the Tweed, seaward, were likely that dayto bear no freight more sacred to love and romance than—fish IWe were over the Tweed, at last, and running along upBerwickshire towards the Lothians, not often within view ofthe sea, and yet near enough for occasional flashes to remindme that only a mile or two away, " between St. Abb's Headand the little village of Eyemouth," as the author of Waverleyexpresses it, those waters were kissing the very rockswhere stood that old tower of Edgar Ravenswood.
